comments.commentBody: It sounds exactly how he probably handled the briefing about the raid in Yemen. "Yeah, that sounds good. Can someone get me some more meat loaf?"

@tom; RS; Deborah:

So all these Senators met with the Russian ambassador but forgot? Oh my! I guess integrity doesn't mean anything unless it's the opposing party, right? And Deborah, if you don't understand the relationship between illegal immigration lowering wages and reducing job opportunities for entry-level job seekers, and lower skills citizen candidates, you aren't paying attention or you deliberately ignore the data.

My point is if you want ethics purity, police your own, first. Hillary, the DNC and their collusions with mainstream media were sickening and turned people to vote for someone who wasn't so corrupt. Bernie was an option, but those parties made sure he didn't win the nomination. So now you're complaining about Trump being elected and trying to destroy his legitimacy by any means necessary. What hypocrisy. Democrats have nothing to offer the American people, since they prioritized illegals over citizens and legal immigrants, and identity groups over America the whole.

I'm not saying the Republicans are perfect either. But Trump and his team have a plan. And part of that plan is enforcing immigration law. I know that this drives hard Dems like you crazy but it's actually refreshing that the rest of us see the law being applied equally on this important issue.

Stop the fake outrage after totally planting this story, (well) timed to take the news away from Trump excellent speech to Congress.

As far as Sessions being "affable", I don't believe I would be willing to list any of these Republican congress-persons on my resume as references or as "friends".  Just the thought of being associated with him, or most of the others, causes me to feel I need to take a shower...and not a cold one.
This all just keeps getting better and better.  The House of Trump is falling apart as we speak.  My advice: start drinking heavily.  Sit back and enjoy the show.

It will be interesting to see how many times Jeff Sessions had met with the Russian ambassador prior to Trump being the nominee of the republican party and what was the agenda. If he did not meet with him for a few years and then meets twice in three months during a heated election campaign we will get the message. Someone please follow up !

We're the crybabies?

Nobody show him mr. trump's Tweet storms...

It's got something to do with that sneering grin which links Sessions and W. Bush Jr. for that bad odor of "I've really got something to hide." However W. seems so reasonable,...now. Sigh.... The one thing that all three smiley faces have in common is how passionately excited they get when lying.
Go Gail Collins!!
Put him in Jail.
Mr. Trump could dispel much distrust and suspicion simply by releasing his taxes.

Why have we only been seeing smoke with no fire? Perhaps there are no facts to support the allegations of Administration wrongdoing with Russia. Perhaps the contacts with Russians were merely perfunctory. There are really no facts upon which to base investigations, just innuendo.
Why?
Follow the money---always follow the money....and you will find the Trump/Russian connection.

Obama wiretapped Trump during the election???  This is third world Banana Republic stuff of the highest level.  Waaay beyond Nixon and even Hillary.  Time to purge the swamp!  AG Sessions will pursue this, how delicious!

I don't think Obama knows how to wiretapping.

But he does know the procedure for getting court authorization for a wire tap.
Yup, and Trump seems to understand the judge demanded more evidence, and then granted the FISA order.

Sessions' defense against possible perjury charges is that he "misspoke" in a very important answer to a very important question during his confirmation hearing for Attorney General before the U.S. Senate?  Am I the only one who is amazed that the man Trump nominated and the Republicans confirmed to be Attorney General is a self admitted incompetent attorney?

Ahhh! But Scottie, you've got to consider that, once people have finally received Health Care--maybe not the Cadillac Plan that you have--what they had been lacking was quickly becoming apparent. The Unions were asking that the workers receive their rightful slice of the pie; but, you order: "Let them eat cake!"

Remember that that cake bit goes back almost two and a-half centuries, when another group of Constituents who, in that case, had been left out of of the French Dream. Yes, the GOP is quite good at parsing their words, but Barack Obama showed that those same words can be used to feed the people, cure the sick, etc, and not just pull the wool down over their eyes.

Tell me, Scottie, why have you strangled one of the finest public university systems, just because the professors--as well as the students--have learned to differentiate right-from-wrong, once they considered all of the facts, not just the ones that you, and the GOP, wish to reveal.

https://thetruthoncommonsense.com
SCOTT WALKER?   You're kidding.  How did Trump manage NOT to give HIM a cabinet position?  "Stood strong in our fight for taxpayers."  What mockery.

"...we did just that by taking on public-sector unions that had too much control over the government."

While Walker makes it sound as though he opposed public-sector unions to preserve Wisconsin's fiscal solvency, he actually cherry-picked which public-sector unions to target based on the least objective (but not least surprising) criterion -- whether or not they supported him.
http://archive.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/unions-that-backed-walker...
So teachers (who earn no overtime pay) were sleeping in the state house to protest his measures against them, but police (who can earn overtime pay, which could be deleterious to a state's budget) had no worries.

Nice try, Walker, but your dishonesty is showing.
One word, Kansas

This con man gives one sided advice: returning "power" to the states, but without also returning the revenue that the gov't currently uses for the safety net programs that are slated for being dropped.  Instead plans for that revenue have it being diverted to the military, a border wall, and tax breaks for rich people.  This leaves the states with no means to proceed on their own.  A real con artist.

It’s interesting how Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker distinguishes “voters” who protest his policies and “the people” who he claims his unpopular, ruinous policies support, but then contradicts himself when he urges Republicans to damn the People’s will or opposition, full speed ahead. In his “system” an elected official is not there to serve the whole community, only specific parts of it. What has been so troubling from Republicans, including Trump, who challenged the majority of America who is horrified by his agenda, to set aside “trivial fights” – as if life/death health care is “trivial”, or shutting down climate action and diplomacy in favor of “historic” expansion of military hardware – is that Republicans never have any intention of trying to accommodate the objections. Throughout the Obama Administration and now, Republicans idea of “unity” is “do what we say or we will crush you.” Obama desperately tried to bring Republicans into the health care discussion – remember that U-shaped table discussion where Obama sat for hours pleading to hear other ideas – and as for “state’s rights” as Walker asserts is the be-all-and-end-all, the Affordable Care Act (as well as the Clean Energy Plan) allowed for states to come up with their own solutions as long as they met minimal criteria. But as for state control of such vital things as health care, that sets up a situation of unequal protection among Americans based on zipcode.

I am reminded of the Mel Brooks dialog :

Advisor : "The people are revolting!"
King : "Yes they are!"

Mr. Walker finds demovracy and public protest so annoying and wonders why he can use troops to sweep them away.
Governor Walker does not stipulate that returning authority to the states is an empty gesture, unless the Federal Government also returns the funds we send to Washington to pay for governance.

I don't think the teachers unions supported Walker or Trump for record. The Demonstrators in Madison at the time of Act 10 were largely teachers and other government workers who did not support the idea of paying for some of their salaries for benefits.  Look who was protesting Devos hearings in the Senate. The Democratic party gets most of its funding from unions especially public sector unions. They tried to stop Walker and failed.

Thank you Mr. Walker for writing such an excellent piece. I could not agree with you more.  The states should govern and not the federal government.  They know the needs of the people not Washington.  I voted Republican all the way down the ballot and it is articles like this that give me hope in Ameroca's future.  I must admit I was surprised that the NYT would allow such a piece like yours.  Maybe they are listening to their minority conservative readership for a change.  Thank you for writing this.
